title: A rope roll for an ice bucket

description.text:
My wife broke her arm and she got a cooling 'sleeve' which is connected to a bucket full of ice. By lowering the bucket for a minute and raising it again, the water is re-cooled in the bucket and then flows back into the sleeve. She wanted to do this without help, so I made this.

It's far from perfect - but it works.

I used two 608-bearings and a counterweight for the bucket.

Also, two 30mm M4 screws and two corresponding nuts.

comments.text: Can you post a few more instructions on the assembly and particularly the trigger. Having difficult time with it. Any advice would be appreciated
comments.author: rshenson

comments.text: The trigger is a little tricky. Basically you need a short section (about 3/8'') of rod. Glue one end of the rod into the hole in one half of the trigger handle, wait for it to dry, and then slide it into the hole in the gun. Then carefully glue on the other half making sure to line it up with the half that is already on. Also do not glue the trigger to the gun body as it is held on by the rod. I hope this helps, it has been awhile since I have made this.
comments.author: rshenson

description.text:
German below

DJI Phantom 3 camera lens cover

This beautifully designed lens cover is for the 4K main camera of DJI Phantom 3 drone. It fits perfectly and, thanks to its rounded corners it can also cause scratches nowhere.

Inside is also a small spacer ring available for the glass ensures that the do not directly come into contact with the lens cap and thus prevents scratches by own fault. Many others are not aware of the PLA and ABS printed objects may well have put sharp. The ribbing on the outer housing also provides a secure feeling when and stake out. Fits Phantom 3 Professional and Advanced.

You can also cover the cover in our online shop http://www.drohnenshop-berlin.de/DJI-Phantom-3-camera-lens-cover

More about the drones fly you get on my German-speaking side under http://www.BerlinerARdrone.de and on YouTube at http://www.youtube.com/BerlinerARdrone.

DJI Phantom 3 Linsenabdeckung

Diese Formschöne Linsenabdeckung ist für die 4K Hauptkamera der DJI Phantom 3 Drohne. Sie passt hervorragend an die Kamera Einheit und dank ihrer abgerundeten Ecken kann sie auch Nirgendwo Kratzer verursachen.

Im inneren ist ebenfalls ein kleiner Abstandsring vorhanden der dafür sorgt das dass Glas nicht direkt mit der Linsenabdeckung in Berührung kommt und somit Kratzer durch Eigenverschulden vorbeugt. Viele User berücksichtigen nicht, das auch PLA und ABS gedruckte Objekte durchaus scharfe stellen haben können. Die Riffelung am Gehäuse äußeren bietet zusätzlich ein sicheres Gefühl beim auf und ab stecken. Passend für Phantom 3 Professional und Advanced.

Die Abdeckung können Sie auch bei uns im Onlineshop fertig gedruckt Kaufen http://www.drohnenshop-berlin.de/DJI-Phantom-3-Linsen-Abdeckung

Mehr über das Drohnen Fliegen bekommt ihr auf meiner Deutschsprachigen Seite unter http://www.BerlinerARdrone.de sowie bei Youtube unter http://www.youtube.com/BerlinerARdrone

The motorcycle stand was always in the way no matter where I stored it. And since we all play in the world of 3D up it went on the wall.

I didn't print it 100% solid and i overtighten one of the 4 screwws and sure enough it cracked a little. Didn't seem to affect it, but only time will tell I guess.
I did pull on the hook with way more weight then the stand so I think it will stand the test of time? HA! if that doesn't make you want to print it I don't know what will lol.
The diameter of the stand is roughly 33mm and I made the ID on the hook 35mm. Gave it some support on the base and looks great actually.
My stand is heavvier on one side hence the offset, but one hook should be enough.

description.text:
This solder holder can be used to mount it anywhere.

Use the pipe length to make a bigger or a smaller solder holder.

The cap can be fixed with M5 screws.

print 2x cap.stl, 2x holder and one pipe.

You can use the scaling function of your slicer to make the pipe smaller or bigger.

Use a M5 screw to mount the cap on the pipe.

Use M3 screws to mount the holder anywhere!

This 60 floor hotel is the only 7 star hotel in the world. The Burj Al Arab was the first hotel to ever surpass the height of 1000ft and cost 650 million dollars to create. The Royal suite in this luxury hotel is only used by the wealthiest of people because of the 24,000 dollar a night cost. The helipad on the top of the building has been used for many promotional activities such as, Tiger Woods hitting a tee shot or an F1 driver doing donuts on it.

I reccommend printing this at a reasonably large size, possibly 100 to 110% or larger. Set the quality to high otherwise it struggles with the supports on the side. The most successful print i did was on its front or when it was standing vertically. Supports are definatly needed because of the heli pad at the top of the building. When printed i set the density to 25% which seemed to work just fine.

Spool and filament storage to replace the internal storage which is incompatible with non-Flashforge plastic.

Prints without support and uses approximately 35m of plastic. See instructions for more detailed information.

Prints on a Flashforge Dreamer (Minimum Printer Bed Dimensions 110mm x 230mm x 60mm)

Print //
2x Spool Holder Mounts, 1x Spool Holder Arm Left and 1x Spool Holder Arm Right.

My Settings with Black and Grey ABS //
0.3mm Layers
20% Line Infill
80mm/s Print and Travel Speed
220C Extruder Temperature
110C Bed Temperature
Fans: Auto

Other Components Required //

8mm dia. Threaded Rod, 8mm dia. Steel or Aluminium Bar or Tube. I advise using metal as you could potentially have up to 6kg of plastic suspended between the arms and plastic or wood is likely to bend or snap.

Installation //
1) Firstly ensure the printer is off and cooled down.

2) Remove the four bolts from the back exterior of the printer which secure the X and Y axis movement pulleys with an Allen key, ensuring the small nuts do not get lost in the inside of the printer.

3) Reinsert two bolts into each Spool Holder Mount and fit them into the back of the printer with the chamfered ends facing up.

4) Apply TRULOC or a similar product to the bolts and reinsert the nuts. Be careful not to tighten them too much with the Allen key as it could damage the printer or Spool Holder Mount.

5) Slide the Spool Holder Arms into the Spool Holder Mounts with the chamfered edges facing outwards.

6) Arrange your spools and filament onto the bar or rod and fit it into the Spool Holder Arms.

Notes //
I am working on arms which are compatible with a range of diameters of bar.

I am also working on a filament feeding design which will utilise the tube that came with the printer.

Printing at a higher fill % would obviously be stronger but 20% seems to be sufficient thus far. I will update you after I have tested the design for a while. You can also print at a lower layer height but the design works perfectly well at 0.3mm.

With this design you will have to modify your lid if you print with it on for materials like ABS; I will upload a photo of my modifications that work best with the printer soon.

Please message me with any queries about the design or improvements I could make and I will endeavour to get back to you within a day.

description.text:
I did a little sketch with iTracer on my iPhone and printed the object with a MakerBot. Quite easy, but I had to change the 3DS-file that iTracer exported to a STL-file with Meshlab and the size of the object in Blender. But there's still a lot of software involved:
iTracer -> Mail -> Meshlab -> Blender -> Skeinforge -> ReplicatorG What we need now is a 3D scanner app for the iPhone!

• design an object with iTracer on your iPhone
  • export the model (it's send as an email to your account)
  • open the 3DS-file with Meshlab
  • export as STL-file
  • you can adjust the size of your object with Blender.
  • process the STL with Skeinforge (generates a G-Code file for the MakerBot)
  • print the G-Code file with ReplicatorG and a MakerBot

author: jojohio

description.text: Nice snug fit.

The spool manager that was provided by airwolf3d for printing is AWESOME! Unfortunately none of my current spools have the larger hole they all use the smaller hole. Not a problem! A simple removal of the spool hub and some reengineering of the existing hardware and you are in business.
  • Print the design here and assemble as instructed here http://airwolf3d.com/blog/2013/03/22/download-3d-printer-spool-minder/ except for the large 33mm bolt
  • Remove all of the nuts, washers and bearing wheels on the provided spool rod that you got with your printer.
  • Push the rod all the way through the hole leaving about 6.5 inches between the acrylic frame.
  • attach a washer and nut to secure to the right side of the frame leg (if facing the front of the printer)
  • thread the printed spool manager on the rod and then put a washer and bolt you removed originally and tighten it down.
  • now put the large washer you removed originally on and one of the bearing wheels.
  • thread another washen then bolt on and tighten.
  • figure out the spacing needed for your spool (Mine is about 6 inches) and put another bolt then washer.
  • put the other wheel bearing on and another washer then bolt.
  • put your spool on and put the second large washer and the final bolt.
    • This should allow it to spin free and get all of the benefits of the spool minder.
    HUGE thanks to Airwolf3d for an AMAZING printer and a really great spool minder. The original is available here http://airwolf3d.com/blog/2013/03/22/download-3d-printer-spool-minder/

a little "roller coaster" that is powered by a windmill

note: the last picture shows how all the parts go together, but it was taken before the windmill blade and the ride base where changed.

i designed this on 123D, it is easy to put together all you have to do is put the windmill shaft through the hole on top of the windmill base. the put the windmill pulley on the shaft, next put the blade shaft through the small hole on the top of the windmill base then put the blade on that shaft. that completes the windmill, now you need to construct the ride. first insert the ride shaft into the top of the ride base, then put the pulley on that shaft, attach the car and arm to the small hole on the top of the shaft and press the car into the groove on the outside of the base. the last thing to do is to add a rubber band of some type of string between the 2 pulleys.

description.text: A spool clip for 1.75mm Velleman filament spools. It is 10mm thick by default, but you can scale the Z dimension to change this

Print these at 0.2mm layer height. Use a low infill, if any, as this will keep them flexible enough to snap over the lip of the spool. Because these are so small, you can print several at once without increasing the overall print time by much. I printed four of these in about fifteen minutes, whereas one would take about ten minutes to print.

title: Openbuilds v-slot Y axis for Lulzbot TAZ 3, 4, 5 or 6 printers

description.text:
This project adds a bolt on, no firmware modification required fully supported Y axis to the Lulzbot Taz 3, 4 and 5 printers in place of the existing bearing rods. This project is compatible with the layout of the Taz 3. You will need to drill 4 highly precise holes in a new or existing Taz 3-5 heated bed mount plate to accommodate the Openrail hardware.
Build thread is here: https://forum.lulzbot.com/viewtopic.php?f=16&t=2426

Video of the completed modification in action: https://youtu.be/79-YFZdIeOM

If you downloaded the 1.0a version of the corners, they were 4mm too tall at the very tip. You can easily cut that off without affecting the part, or download the corrected 1.1a variant and reprint it.

The new Version 2.0 parts move the rail outboard 1mm per side to better engage the wheels.

Update 2:

The two Idler and Motor endplate reinforcement plates are designed to allow for easier rail allignment in parallel. The first release was off a bit, Version 2.0 is corrected, pictures to come shortly, You will need to tap the end of the Openrails with an M5 Tap to be able to use these plates (the two outside holes on the front and all 4 holes on the back), and they should be considered optional.

The other addition is an optional Combined Drill Guide. It has the spacing set between the small fixed and large exxentric holes fixed. It's a thicker plate, which will hopefully make it more effective. it also has smaller holes for the bolts, so it shouldn't be able to move around as much anyways. This one does use significantly more plastic than the other ones, but it should thoretically be easier to use. You'll want to print two of them and make sure they both line up when you drill your holes. The X allignment (side to side) is absolutly critical for the drill guide. The Y allignment doesn't really matter.

Update 3. New version of the Combined Drill plate now uploaded. The old one was apperently too close together.

Update 4: It turns out the motor mount metal plate from the Taz 3 is 4mm different than the one in the Taz 4/5 in important areas. This means the back reinforcing plate will not fit a 4/5 yet. A 4/5 specific variant will be uploaded tonight. In my defense I don't have a Taz 4 or 5 Chassis to test the plate on hehe.

Update 5: Version E of the 4/5 motor endplate, the holes are right now I think.

Note: This will fit a Taz 6.

Update 6: The new idler front plate has a small recess to accomodate the new Y axis belt tensioner tension bolt http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1656341 It is otherwise unchanged from the 1.0_a revision.

Update 7: The Taz 6 bed plate has 4mm wider spacing on the stock bearing mount holes. There is now an uploaded drilling guide that takes that into account.

Update 8: The long awaited instructions document is now uploaded!

Update 9, uploaded an updated Taz 6 specific endplate.

You will need to source 2x 500mm 20mm x 40mm Openrail extrusions, 4 Openrail

2x 40mm x 20mm Openbuilds linear extrusion, 500mm long. http://openbuildspartstore.com/black-v-slot-linear-rail/
4 sets of bearing wheels (http://openbuildspartstore.com/xtreme-solid-v-wheel-kit/ or other sets) ,
2 spacers (6mm) http://openbuildspartstore.com/aluminum-spacers/
2 eccentric spacers http://openbuildspartstore.com/eccentric-spacer/
Bolts and nuts (M5, Lengths to be determined.)
M5 Heat set nuts (Mcmaster Carr has them)
1 Taz 5 heated bed mounting plate (the Aluminum thingy) that you can drill into with a drill press, can be purchased from Lulzbot if you don't want to risk your existing one for $35
The printed parts (4 end pieces, 6 middle supports, and theoretically the Drill Guide(s)

You may also want these two drill bits:
http://www.mcmaster.com/#catalog/121/2427/=zy8ysr

Metric Black&Gold Oxide High-Speed Steel Jobbers Drill Bit
7.2mm, 108mm Overall Length, 71.4mm Drill Depth, 135 Degree Point
30565A296

Metric Black&Gold Oxide High-Speed Steel Jobbers Drill Bit
5.0mm, 92mm Overall Length, 61.1mm Drill Depth, 135 Degree Point
30565A272

7.2mm is the exact size of the eccentric wheel adjuster

Using the existing Y bed structure as a base, remove the Rod mount end pieces and any attached hardware. You will also need to remove at least one of the Y bed mounts from each existing 500mm long 20mm rail. Now install 3 bed support pieces per side, one in the middle, then the bed mount you removed, then one on either end. They should be spaced evenly. Now install the new endcaps and the new Openrails.

Next, take your bed plate and Drill template(s) and drill the holes in the indicated locations. Precision is key here. You only have about 1-2mm adjustability so if you are off, you start over with a new plate. A drill press, precision clamping, a realllly good carbide drill bit set, and patience are highly recommended.

Once that is finished, install the Openrail wheels in the bed plate and slide it onto the new bed rails. Adjust tensions as needed until the bed moves smoothly with no play at all.

You do not need to edit firmware or anything along those lines to get this to work. Aside from the hole drilling, it's a bolt on modification.

Full parts list (Thank you mikronano for writing this up):
Spacers ( 6x - each):
(2) M5 x 10mm
(2) M5 washers
(2) T-nuts
so if you use six spacers you'll need (12) for each of the above

Front Rail Ends (Idler):
(6) M5 x 10mm (use on the T-nuts)
(6) M5 x 20mm (use upfront on the End Plate)
(12) M5 washers
(2) M5 heat inserts (i.e. product#94180A361 M5x6.7mm from McMaster-Carr will do just fine)
(2) M3 x 16mm (for the upper holes upfront on the End Plate and all the way back to the Idler)

Rear Rail Ends (Motor):
(6) M5 x 10mm (use on the T-nuts)
(8) M5 x 20mm (use upfront on the End Plate)
(14) M5 washers
(2) M5 heat inserts (same M5x6.7mm)
(2) M3 x 16mm (for the upper holes upfront on the End Plate and all the way back to the Motor)

Wheels:
(4) M5 x 30mm (I personally prefer the "Low Profile" from OpenBuilds because they're the only ones that I can find with Full Threads)
(12) M5 washers

comments.text: The longest extrusion openbuilds offers are 1500mm long. You could go longer with a join splice assuming good support and alignment. At that Pont available bed heater size and belt tension start to become issues. A 500mm x 500mm bed has been done. Larger than that would require custom electronics (bed heater) and maybe a nema34 motor and bigger belt but the frame can go quite large without issue.

author: zorco

description.text:
Complete set to replace the carriage, left and right XY mount for use of standard 24mm LM8UU (plain) bearings.It contains also the modified cable chain stepper mount for this cable chain: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:124700 and also a specific screw-less "quick-clip" cooling fan mount matching to the carriage.

The goal of this project is to have a good replacement for use of IGUS plain bearings. The challenge was to create a bearing sleeve without any deforming of the bearings caused by fixing screws. So, the solution is the use of snap rings and additional grub screws. Now it's possible to adjust the right fixity for a good slide without loosing of the bearings if the screw too slack.

I recommend to print all parts with ASA filament - it's like ABS, but more stable and heat resistant until 120°C. Important is good calibration of the printer to achieve a good accuracy of the bearing sleeves.

All parts (exclude snap rings):

  • 0.2mm layer height
  • 30-60% infill
  • min. 3 shells
  • vertical print of all bearing parts!
  • enable support, but remove support inside of the bearing sleeves before printing (if it's possible)

Snap rings:

  • 0.1mm layer height
  • 100% infill

Important hints...

  • Use fine sand paper wrapped around a round bar to bring the bearing sleeves to the correct size
  • The bearings must fall solely in the sleeve by its own weight
  • Use a vertical 8mm round steel to make the fall test with inserted bearings (see pictures).
  • The holes for the grub screws are printed with a diameter of 3.4mm - use a M4 tapper to cut the thread for the final size.

title: Improved Toolhead adapter for RepMan to Thing-O-Matic

description.text:
THIS IMPROVED ADAPTER IS A WORK IN PROGRESS.
I HOPE TO TEST IT NEXT WEEKEND ON GulaschProgrammierNacht. Improvement:
  • use a third M5 hole that already exists in the Thing-o-Matic to stabilize the adapter against backlash in milling
  • grip the edge of the toolhead-platform for added stability
    • This should allow me to do the PCB milling much faster without loosing precision to backlash. Blog post: http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.com/2011/06/improved-repman-to-tom-toolhead-adapter.html original video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z14gkPYD0aI === I made this adapter, so I could reuse my very stable Dremel milling-head on the new Thing-O-Matic.
    Any RepMan-toolhead should fit with this adapter. I oriented the part, so that it prints well on a Thing-O-Matic.
I designed the grip for the edge of the toolhead-platform 1mm smaller then the DXF-files to accomodate for inprecise printing.

A replacement knob for a Roper electric stove. We've never been able to find replacement knobs that will work on this stove so I went ahead and made a new model based on our last surviving knob.

Update: Added a split version that does not require supports but will require glue. Useful if your slicer or printer has issues with supports or you just don't like them.

The notch in the key part should be on rotated so it's in line with the fat part of the grip on the other piece.

Example was printed in PLA with supports and a raft.
Layer Height: .2mm
Infill: 20%
2 Shells

Recommend you print with top of the knob up for the cleanest finish.

There is a small indentation at the narrow end to hold paint for an indicator if you would like to make it more visible.

author: soccerdrew

description.text:
I, like Mario Batali and most school children, own a pair of crocs.  Mine are lined and are great for walking the dog in cold weather.  
I've often wondered why they would intentionally leave those iconic holes open on the top. These things are supposed to be keeping me warm!  My guess is that they wanted me fill them with those charms they sell, thereby giving them some extra money.
Well 3D printing to the rescue!  I made myself a nice set of spikes to plug those holes, and I got to keep my money.
I doubt anyone will want their own set of croc spikes, but there MAY be some interest in using the base to make derivatives.  These charms are a quick print (5-10min.)  What a nice thing to give to a young kid to get them excited about 3D printing.  Maybe the makerbot M? or, um... a bunny rabbit? ...the bust of Colbert?

comments.text: Would have loved to have had them in school. Imagine kicking someone in the behind with these!

title: Sorpion V-Tail Quadcopter new lighter parts.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my version of a V-tail copter. Im useing 1000 KV Motors and 12 amp ESC's as well as the Crius Multi Wii SE control board. This thing flys very well. I built a few Quad X copters, but it is very easy to lose orintation with them because they look the same from all angles.
Not this baby, I fly it like an airplane.
The STL's Are for a Prusa Mendel, with a 200mm x200mm build platform. some of the pieces have to be positioned corner to corner.
This is a big copter 420mm front to back. And 450 across the arms. (Update)
These file are the latest verision as of 5/27/2013. The total weight with all hardware, ready to fly is 730 g. Not including batery.
The full STL is only for viewing in 3D. It is much to big to print as one piece. Here is a video of the first test flight. http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_detailpage&v=uggPmShPEp0

author: FrankenForge

description.text: Sun/light shroud for 7 inch led/lcd/TFT monitors for FPV - important you print it in 'high quality' on the Replicator 2 options - otherwise it prints very 'stringy' on the inside face print. If you print it on 'fast' settings, I dealt with this by applying PVA to the inside surface of the print when finished, to bond the stringiness together and it worked really well. Can spray paint it after that if your'e fussy :-) I only print using PLA (not ABS). SEE also Mk2 - thinner, simpler, quicker to build and works well for purpose - print in High Quality 15% fill, Shells 3, Layer 0.10 If you experience 'banding' on the first layer, don't worry it doesn't seem to affect the final finish. Don't know why it does this - maybe something in the Makerbot ware to stop warping??? Outer finish off build plate is fine (the outside aesthetic look - see pics) Super-glue (CA glue) the bevelled faces together to form the shroud as one piece if you prefer (I did). Velcro strips on the outside of the monitor frame - mid 1/3 top, mid 1/3 left and mid 1/3 right and the hook on the opposite inside the printed frame secures it perfectly. Newbe here .... my first submission - picture is rubbish - thingi works well for purpose !! I promise to get better at this :-)
Second Pistol I designed today. I'm practicing cad and design work to get my brain going. Hope everyone likes it. Its cut up into pieces to fit on any 3D printer.

comments.text:
Okay, this is a clean NASA Wrench stl file that is designed by the company who put the first 3d printer in space. Company name is Made in space. They had overheard an astronaut say I need a Wrench or rachet, I can't remember, and so the company made in space got to designing it right away. I just put it on because every other one I tried, would not slic3 correctly. So this is a copy of there design. And I posted a gcode file so others can just print from a Prusa i3.
I had just got done uploading a video on it and will be editing it next and posting it. Many have just modified thus version.
Print the mirror image and you can get one that lossens ccw, as this one only tightens cw.

remixed_from.title: Yet another Raspberry PI case - V2

title: Raspberry Case with I/O cable slot access - Built on Yet Another Case.

description.text:
This is built from the design supplied by mihalko.  I cleaned the model of spurious triangles, touched up the dimensions, and added a slot for the I/O cable interface.  Supplied are the STL, Sketch-up, and Inventor Fusion files for your edification.  Would be glad to adjust if you find any issues.  
Included are the top with Raspberry Logo, Bottom, and Rails (Print 2) so you can stack them and allow air to flow.  
Thanks to all those before that supplied the work thus far.  
This should be the final version.  I redrew the bottom because the original sketchUp file was inconsistent.  Also adjusted a few of the features for a better fit.  Enjoy.

comments.text: Fixed the problems with the model and redrew the bottom because of inconsistencies.  Adjusted a few of the features in both parts.  Models and .STLs uploaded.  Enjoy.
comments.author: dmyers7

comments.text: Ok, printed the bottom half after slicing with Cura.  Overall not bad, but there are a few features that interfere with the board once installed.   I will be redrawing the bottom using Inventor Fusion (my goto tool on my MAC).  One main reason to use Fusion is that I want to be able to slice it in Slicr (fix the errors in the model) and it's the quickest way for me to redraw & edit for future changes, and I like Fusion.  One of the issues is the I/O cable from ADAfruit runs into the side of the case, the main reason I started this project.  So look for my updated files soon.
comments.author: dmyers7

comments.text: Slicing the bottom with Slicer 0.9.9 does not process correctly.  Cura seams to do a good job.  Will be looking at the SketchUp file for a fix.  I appreciate any feedback.  Will also try printing the output from Cura as temporary fix.

description.text:
Mini acrobatic / racing non-FPV quadcopter

This is my latest design straight out of sketchup! :D
Totally printable sans wooden booms and electronics, I designed this quad to be a replacement for all the nano-qx type things I had burnt out over the (would say years, more like weeks).

Specs

  • Flight controller mounting point spacing: 30.5mm (KKMini, CC3D)
    Booms: 10mm x 10mm, x2 95mm, x1 200mm

Whats Printable:

  • Top and bottom plates
    Triangular motor mount

Required hardware:

  • x8 M3 bolts for motor mounts, and mounting flight controller
    x12 bolts (and nuts if necsessary) to mount motors (whatever size works for you, holes are undershot)

Required electronics:

  • x4 motors (15mm triangular spacing)
    x4 ESCs
    Receiver, flight controller, etc.

Battery:

  • Well under or up to 1300mah, or 90 some grams seemed good at the time.

Note: No battery strap slots yet, thats in Rev. 2 :)

Case is a remix of: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:604915

Some markets sell inexpensive spices in the ethnic food sections, but they are bagged and need a jar. Spice jars There are 3 parts, the jar, cap and the disk. The jar part can be printed with no raft, and using default Afinia settings (figure 0.30 mm Z-resolution and medium speed). The cap and disk have important details and require a bit more care. They should be printed at 0.20 mm Z, or less, on a raft, and using the "Fine" Quality (slow speed) setting. "Normal" quality works, but doesn't print the details as well. I printed all 3 parts right side up. That means the cap will be filled with support material, which is a chore to remove. However, the little pivot-pin on its top is critical and if printed upside down, the pin can get distorted. I tried many adjustments but the upside-down cap is a tough one. Maybe you'll have better luck if you try it.
Another benefit is the top, visible surfaces print clean, without suffering pockmarks from support attachment points. (For those that have fan cooling options, you might want to cool the pin as it prints to prevent it getting too soft, and distorting.) Pushing the disk over the cap's little pivot-pin requires some carefully directed force, but it will snap on and stay on. The 2 inch "jar" portion can be scaled up or down (Z-scaled) if you want to, but I wouldn't expect good results if the diameter (X and Y) of any parts are changed. I made a couple of short jars by just aborting the print when the time was right.

title: Toyota M8x1.25 - M12x1.25 gear knob adapter

description.text:
Hey guys,

Been playing around with the idea of installing a fully sick "dilly" style gear knob in my wife's yaris, because, you know, whats life without a bit of whimsy!

She has an auto yaris, which runs a M8x1.25 thread on the shifter, and the knob i had laying around was a M12x1.25, so it wasnt a straight fit unfortunately...

So, cue the music...

I fabbed this lil bad boy up, a nice simple gear adapter. the modeling side of things was done by using sketchup, and using mike_linus's http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193647

enjoy!

(the adapter isnt the prettiest model, but it works!)

Have printed it at 100% infill using Bilby3d's translucent red PLA.

seems sturdy enough! time will tell!

Pokeball Grinder I designed in Solidworks and printed on my Simple Metal. It has been updated slightly after I had printed it. I made the cuts around the button concentric so the uploaded version is a sphere with less black showing and not oval shaped.

The grinder insert marked as "engraved" just had my user name around the rim, chose the non engraved one if you don't want to see my name, just added it for the fun of it. Let me know if you have any ideas to improve it and show me your prints!!!

I printed everything with a .2mm later thickness and supported. The outer parts and stand can be low infill, I recommend a high infill for the grinder inserts to make the teeth a bit stronger. I haven't had any teeth break on me, but just in case you can yank out an insert with pliers and put in a new one

Everything is press fit so the only thing I recommend for assembly is some sandpaper if you're having trouble putting parts together. Don't be afraid to put your weight into it when pressing the parts together just be smart about it. Happy printing!

The head of the Dota 2 hero Windranger.

Original model downloaded from the Dota2 Workshop and imported into Blender.

I chopped off the pony-tail, and the head, filled the gaps and added a base. Finally, I`ve made everything hollow to save material.

Took me about 2-3 weeks of work during the evenings to get it right (learn to use Blender and fix all the modelling issues that would have caused problems when printing).

If anybody is interested in the Blender project file, let me know.

I really hope you like it and if you have any questions, suggestions or remarks, please let me know in the comments.

Check out the video time-lapse at https://youtu.be/0x0vN09vsSY

Enjoy!

Standard dimensions set in the model should be approximately:
7 cm tall
7.5-8 cm wide (base diameter)

Weight: 25g (including supports)

Feel free to scale it.

I have printed it with PLA, hollow and used the "Hollow Thick Walls" option on my M3D printer, which is the second option in terms of wall thickness that the printing software offers.

For layer resolution, I have used the "Medium" option, which should translate to 0.2mm as far as I understand.

Did not use a raft since the model already has a base for ballancing, but I enabled the "Print with supports material" and "Model on model supports" options which uses the printing software's algorithm for handling overhangs by adding support material.

I also used the "Wave bonding" option to make sure the bottom sticks nicely to the print bed (since the base covers a large area), but if you are using PLA this should not be needed.

Print time: 13 hours using the "best" quality STL file.
(let me know how if you did it faster or better :) )

Enjoy and leave your comments!

description.text:
This is a replacement filament holder for the Davinci Junior. It holds your NFC chip and the filament so you don't have to change out the holder everytime you want to change filament. It might need slight sanding or tweaking but should slide together a little tight which keeps you from needing the screw.

Current Versions are the V2 files.

UPDATE: I uploaded the two pieces seperately for ease of printing. Also caught a spot where there shouldn't of been an opening and filled it in.

UPDATE 12/30/15: FIlament Holder V2, I adjusted the model that holds the chip. The slot where the chip sits in the holder was redesigned with no overhang, meaning less or no trimming. The chip will not snap in as tightly but this shouldn't be a problem once the two halfs are put together.

UPDATE: 5/9/2016: Filament Holder Part A V2, Thickened the walls some to allow for smoother printing with certain printers. Current

title: PieceMaker - Build your own board game pieces
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Make your own pieces, make your own game. Extend an existing board game, bling out your chess set, or make up something completely new! With this board game piece customizer you can choose the height, width, flare, style, taper, and caps to be whatever you like. You can even choose settings that allow you to embed coins inside your print so that your pieces will have more satisfying "heft".

Try out the included demo models or press the "Open in Customizer" button to get started making your own custom board game pieces. All of the pieces in the photo, plus thousands more, can be made by customizing this one model.

Pieces and Games Challenge!

If you design a game piece with PieceMaker, please post a "Make" and use it to describe the name of your piece and what you think its properties should be. Specify rules for your piece about movement, attack, defense, effects on other pieces, effects from other pieces, and any random elements. If you design a set of pieces for a new game, or collect other people's pieces to make a game, then post your game as a remix and describe the rules! If a bunch of good pieces and games come out of this then I'll feature them on Hacktastic.

Weekly Design Challenge Update +1:

It's week three of the epic 3D design battle between me and atartanian, and another contender here in the office is throwing his hat in the ring. Or, rather, I've found his hat and now it is in the ring. This week, 3D modeling legend mannytan is joining the battle! @mannytan, I hereby challenge you join our challenge to post one design a week by the end of every Friday!

Here's a recap of this week's entries:

  • Piecemaker by mathgrrl (this entry)
  • Parametric Pinecone by mannytan
  • atartanian is out this week but will be back for the next round...

description.text:
Tried printing the other one but it literally came apart on me as if it was 2 pieces, sure enough looking at it again on Simplify3D I confirmed there was a gap between them. So I basically redrew this in Fusion 360 as 1 solid piece and while I was at it made a mirror copy so you can print for which side you want it on. You can see in my picture I also printed this other piece of my 6mm tube: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:877258

I printed mine in PLA at 50% infill, tried at 40 and had the tube section start caving in on me (although the section where the tube goes was also smaller on my first attempt).

author: killzu

description.text:
Commentary
This is a old japanese "karakuri" automata mechanized doll "TYAHAKOBI-NINGYOU"

As for this machine, how to make is written in "KIKOUZUI" published in the about 18th century. So it is thought of in older days an original having been made.
This doll carries the teacup which made tea until before of the visitor and performs returning movement automatically to the starting point after having received it.

how to move
1 put it in the flat place.
2 roll up a elastic rubber drum.
3 put a tea-cup on the tray.
4 doll advances.
5 doll stops when take away a tea-cup.
6 doll change direction and come back when put a tea-cup on the tray once again.
7 doll stops when take away a tea-cup.

Parts List---------------------------------------------------

STL parts-------------------------------------------
01_1nowa52 :1st gear
02_tatamisuri45 :right wheel
03_gyoujiwa04 :escape wheel
04_gyoujiwajikuuke01 :3rd gear axis bearing(outside)
05_gyoujiwasinn12 :3rd gear
06_peg01 :nail (4types)
07_kassya01 :pulley
08_tenpu01 :balance
09_tomewasoto03 : elastic cord drum
10_tomewanaka02 : elastic cord rachet
11_2nowa45 :left wheel
12_2nosinn10 :2nd gear
13_tenpujikuuke :balance axis bearing(bottom) (2types)
14_ude03 :both arms(with tray)
15_stoplink :stopper link rod
16_sakigakewa :front wheel
17_sakigakeue01 front wheel frame
18_sokoita03 :base plate
19_sakigakewaku front wheel fork
20_hasirahidari01 :left frame(seeing from the back)
21_nakahasira01 :center frame
22_hasiramigi01 :right frame
23_tatamisurisin :right wheel nut
24_nejimaki :wind up handle
25_teacup02 :tea cup (with cover)
26_muneita01 :balance axis bearing(upper) (2types)
27_gomuklip :elastic cord clip (2types)
28_head01 :head
29_kataita :shoulder board
30_yukimodoriwa :rudder cam (3types)
31_yukimodorilever02 :rudder link rod

used 3Dprinter : PRN3D
head temp :190 degrees centigrade
bed temp :60 degrees centigrade
thickness :0.3mm
filling rates :20%
filament type :PLA

Besides, parts necessary-----------------------------------------------
3mm diameter steel axis X2 (for 1st gear axis,2nd gear axis)
2mm diameter steel axis X8 (for frontwheelaxis,balanceaxis,rudderaxis,ruddercamaxis,escapewheelaxis,armsaxis,pulleyaxisX2)
1mm diameter elastic cord X3(for power,arms,rudderlink)
2mm diameter steel or glass ball(for balance axis bottom bearing)
M3-nuts X2 (for balance weight)
M6-unts X2 (for tea cup weight)
10mm diameter O-ring(for balanceweight fixasion)
16mm diameter O-ring(for front wheel tread)

This model wants you to note that you do not work definitely only by having assembled it.
Adjustment after the assembling is very important to completely operate it.
Particularly, it is important to reduce movement resistance of the mechanism of the escapewheel and balance to keep constant speed enough.

remixed_from.author: DDeGonge888
remixed_from.title: [1.5.1] 3uP - Metal H-Bot Upgrade for QUBD Two-Up

description.text: Simple modification to add core XY drive to 3UP or really any Hbot printer. Print 2 each of the A and B parts, normal and reversed. You'll need two Misumi HBLFSN5-C corner brackets. Also, 4 F624ZZ flanged bearings, 4 M3X35mm screws, 2 M5x8 screws and M3 nuts (Trimcraft RC). Also a length of spacing material to sleeve up from M3 to M4 inside the bearing. I used a brass tube from KS Engineering (Ace Hardware) 5/32x.014 (3.97mm x .355mm) Stock #128. The real trick is to move one drive pulley up 3mm and one down 3mm so that the belt crosses over without touching. The resulting drive is totally smooth and eliminates the Hbot X gantry wiggling. You may need to shorten the inside mounting screw for the stepper motor to keep it from bottoming out. You will also need a belt that is longer to account for the cross between the two driving stepper motors.

comments.author: napierm

comments.text:
• My build is too big and flexible. It is an oversized 3up. I'm currently building a Jetguy/Fredini inspired printer. It uses linear HWIN style rails and will be much stiffer overall.
  • These are the latest STLs. My version numbers aren't all they should be.
  • Yes, it's worth doing if you have a 3up. The corexy does stiffen up the Y movement a lot. Only real problem is that I never did make a good x-slider bottom. What I came up with is just a slight remix of that part with a "bar" of plastic to mate up with the back of the forward belt. Secured it with a cleco clamp. Never posted it because there just has to be a better way.

description.text:
Thanks to the great 3d scanner design from Ferreti, I've adapted to a bubble maker, which uses 2 stepper motors each one with 6 pallets for making bubbles, and 1 usb fan for making the air flow.

Hints
Best way to make liquid composition is to use

  • 6 parts water
  • 2 parts dish soap
  • 1 part sugar or glycerine
    and slowly mix it without making bubbles.

The parts where liquid stay is about 160 ml volume so, based on above hint, I've put 125 ml water + 25 ml dish soap + 1 sugar teaspoon.

Bubble support may not fit perfectly in stepper motor so in my case I've used a lighter to warm a little bit the head of the piece.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=811LwGylLkw

From this thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:702470 download only parts:
1 x http://www.thingiverse.com/download:1128764
1 x http://www.thingiverse.com/download:1128769
1 x http://www.thingiverse.com/download:1128770
1 x http://www.thingiverse.com/download:1128771
1 x http://www.thingiverse.com/download:1128776

and from this thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:280318

1 x http://www.thingiverse.com/download:505597
2 x http://www.thingiverse.com/download:505607

Buy 2 stepper motors like this ones 28BYJ-48 + ULN2003 Driver Board for Arduino, and one Arduino Uno or Nano board. Also you should use a cooler fan or a usb fan to providing the air flow.

After printing all parts and assemble it, download accellstepper library from https://github.com/adafruit/AccelStepper and together with .ino file burn it to arduino board.

How to install arduino board and compile the firmware please reference to http://www.arduino.cc

For electronics supply I've used some solar usb batteries charges, which provides 5 V, perfect for arduino and stepper motor.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/a27bUsL9g8y
